subsections.title: Types of Chemical Bonds
subsections.content: There are three main types of chemical bonds that hold atoms or ions together in compounds.
points: Ionic Bond – formed through transfer of electrons between metals and non-metals.
Covalent Bond – formed through sharing of electrons between non-metal atoms.
Metallic Bond – formed among metal atoms by attraction between ions and delocalised electrons.

subsections.title: Ionic Bonding
subsections.content: Ionic bonding involves the transfer of electrons to form oppositely charged ions which attract each other.
points: Formed between metals (which lose electrons) and non-metals (which gain electrons).
Positive ion (cation) is formed when electrons are lost.
Negative ion (anion) is formed when electrons are gained.
Example: Na + Cl → NaCl, Mg + Cl₂ → MgCl₂, Ca + O → CaO.
Structure: NaCl forms a giant ionic lattice with each Na⁺ surrounded by 6 Cl⁻ ions in a cube shape.

subsections.title: Covalent Bonding
subsections.content: Covalent bonding involves sharing of electrons between non-metal atoms to achieve stable electron arrangements.
points: Forms molecules instead of ions.
Examples include: H₂, Cl₂, NH₃, H₂O, CO₂, N₂, O₂, CH₄.
Each shared pair of electrons forms one covalent bond.
Double and triple bonds are possible (e.g., CO₂ has double bonds; N₂ has a triple bond).

subsections.title: Metallic Bonding
subsections.content: In metallic bonding, metal atoms lose outer electrons that become free to move, creating a sea of delocalised electrons.
points: These electrons are attracted to positive metal ions, forming strong metallic bonds.
Explains properties like high electrical/thermal conductivity and malleability.
Stronger metallic bonds form with more delocalised electrons or if the element is further right in the periodic table.
Examples: Copper (Cu) and Aluminium (Al) – both conduct electricity well.

subsections.title: Applications and Comparisons
subsections.content: Understanding bonding helps explain the properties and behaviours of elements and compounds.
points: Dot and cross diagrams show how electrons are shared or transferred.
Bonding in metals: Sea of delocalised electrons and positive ions.
Covalent compounds like CO₂ have double bonds; CH₄ has single covalent bonds.
Ionic vs Covalent bonding: transfer vs sharing of electrons, forms ions vs molecules, occurs between metals and non-metals vs non-metals only.
Examples of formulas: KCl, CaF₂, Fe₂O₃, H₂O, Al₂O₃, CaBr₂, Na₂O, CO, SiH₄.

subsections.title: Key Definitions and Examples
subsections.content: Definitions and specific examples help reinforce understanding of bonding types.
points: Chemical bond: Force of attraction holding atoms or ions together.
KCl: Ionic bond between potassium and chlorine; stable compound.
Silane (SiH₄): Covalent bonding; 4 shared electrons between silicon and hydrogen.
Better electrical conductors like copper have loosely held outer electrons.

subsections.title: Acids: Definition and Properties
subsections.content: Acids are proton donors with a sour taste and corrosive nature.
points: Sour taste (e.g., lemons, malambe).
pH less than 7.
Turn blue litmus red.
React with metals to produce hydrogen gas.
Conduct electricity in solution.
Enhance rusting of metals.

subsections.title: Groups of Acids
subsections.content: Acids are classified as organic or mineral depending on their source.
points: Organic Acids: Found in plants/animals (e.g., citric, lactic, ethanoic).
Mineral Acids: Lab-made, corrosive (e.g., HCl, H₂SO₄, HNO₃).
Methanoic acid – found in ant and bee stings.
Carbonic acid – in fizzy drinks.
Sulphuric acid – used in car batteries.
Nitric acid – used in fertilizers and explosives.

subsections.title: Uses of Acids
subsections.content: Acids have many industrial, medical, and domestic uses.
points: Car battery manufacture (H₂SO₄).
Fertilizer and detergent production.
Used in making paints, plastics, and explosives.
Food preservation using organic acids.
Carbonate drinks use carbonic acid.
Vinegar and citric acid used in cooking and cleaning.

subsections.title: Bases: Definition and Properties
subsections.content: Bases are substances that accept protons, often bitter and slippery.
points: Bitter taste.
pH above 7.
Turn red litmus blue.
React with acids to form salts.
Conduct electricity in solution.
Enhance rusting when moist.

subsections.title: Groups and Examples of Bases
subsections.content: Bases are classified as natural, inorganic, or alkalis.
points: Natural bases from plant ash (e.g., chidulo).
Inorganic bases made in labs (e.g., NaOH, CaO).
Alkalis are soluble bases (e.g., NaOH, KOH).
NaOH – used in soap and paper making.
Mg(OH)₂ – used as an antacid.
NH₄OH – used in cleaners and fertilizers.

subsections.title: Uses of Bases
subsections.content: Bases are used in industry, medicine, and agriculture.
points: NaOH – soap, petroleum refining, textiles.
Ca(OH)₂ – treats acidic soil and water, used in fungicides.
NH₄OH – removes ink and grease, used in water purification.
MgO – relieves indigestion.
KOH – used in alkaline batteries.

subsections.title: Indicators and pH Scale
subsections.content: Indicators show whether a substance is acidic or basic, and the pH scale measures strength.
points: Litmus: Red in acid, blue in base.
Methyl orange: Pink in acid, yellow in base.
Phenolphthalein: Colourless in acid, pink in base.
Universal indicator shows full pH range from 1 to 14.
pH < 7 is acidic; pH > 7 is basic; pH = 7 is neutral.
Strong acids/bases ionize completely; weak ones ionize partially.

subsections.title: Experiments and Applications
subsections.content: Practical experiments show conductivity, pH, and ionisation levels.
points: Conductivity test: Bright bulb = strong acid/base; dim bulb = weak acid.
Universal indicator test: Colour indicates strength (e.g., red = strong acid, purple = strong base).
Ionisation: HCl ionizes fully; CH₃COOH ionizes partially.
Application: Neutralisation – antacids, soil treatment, toothpaste, insect stings.
Acid + base → salt + water (neutralisation).

subsections.title: Application of Neutralisation
subsections.content: Neutralisation reactions are used in various practical ways to balance acidity and alkalinity.
points: Treat acidic soil with lime (Ca(OH)₂) to improve fertility.
Aid digestion by neutralising excess stomach acid with enzymes.
Treat stomach acid problems using antacids like milk of magnesia.
Toothpaste neutralizes acid in the mouth to prevent tooth decay.
Treat insect stings by applying alkalis to neutralize acidic stings.

subsections.title: Chemical Properties of Acids
subsections.content: Acids react with metals, carbonates, and bases to form different products.
points: Acid + metal → salt + hydrogen gas.
Pop sound confirms hydrogen gas.
Acid + carbonate → salt + CO₂ + water.
Acid + base → salt + water (neutralisation).
Examples: HCl + Mg → MgCl₂ + H₂; CaCO₃ + HCl → CaCl₂ + CO₂ + H₂O.

topics.title: Introduction to Hydrocarbons and Related Concepts

subsections.title: Introduction to Hydrocarbons
subsections.content:
Hydrocarbons are compounds made of hydrogen and carbon only.

Organic chemistry is the study of carbon-containing compounds.
points: Examples of hydrocarbons: petrol, kerosene, LPG (liquefied petroleum gas).

subsections.title: Oxycarbons
subsections.content: Compounds made of carbon and oxygen only.
points: General formula: CₓOᵧ
Examples: CO₂ (carbon dioxide), CO (carbon monoxide).
Usually gases at room temperature.

subsections.title: Catenation
subsections.content: Catenation is the ability of carbon atoms to bond with each other.
points: Carbon forms long chains or rings.
It can also bond with other elements like hydrogen (H), oxygen (O), etc.

subsections.title: Hydrocarbons in Crude Oil
subsections.content: Crude oil is a mixture of hydrocarbons.
points: Used as fuel and raw materials (e.g., plastics, fabrics).

subsections.title: Other Organic Compounds
points: Plant sources: carbohydrates, oils, rubber, textiles.
Animal sources: proteins, fats.

subsections.title: Homologous Series
subsections.content: A group of organic compounds with similar properties.
points: Share a general formula.
Each member differs by a CH₂ group.
Prepared using similar methods.
Gradual change in physical properties.
Similar chemical reactions.
Examples of Homologous Series: Alkanes, Alkenes, Alkynes, Alkanols, Alkanoic acids.

subsections.title: Saturated vs. Unsaturated Hydrocarbons
points: Saturated Hydrocarbons (Alkanes): All carbon-carbon bonds are single. Each carbon is bonded to maximum number of hydrogen atoms.
Unsaturated Hydrocarbons (Alkenes, Alkynes): Contain double or triple carbon-carbon bonds. Fewer hydrogen atoms attached.

Example Saturated:
 H H
 C–C
 H H

Example Unsaturated:
 H H
 C=C
 H H

subsections.title: Test for Unsaturation
subsections.content:
Materials: Test tubes, Acidified potassium permanganate (KMnO₄), Bromine water, Test pipette.

Procedure: Bubble ethene through KMnO₄ and bromine water – observe color changes.
points: Ethene decolorizes KMnO₄ and bromine water.
This confirms the presence of double or triple bonds.
Ethane does not react as it has only single bonds (saturated).

subsections.title: Alkanes
subsections.content: Most common hydrocarbons. No functional group – chemically stable (inert).
points: General formula: CnH₂n+2
Useful for storing reactive elements like alkali metals.
Common Alkanes: Methane, Ethane, Propane, Butane, Pentane, Hexane, Heptane, Octane, Nonane, Decane.

subsections.title: Activity: Derive Molecular Formulas
points: Use the formula CnH₂n+2 to find molecular formulas of:
Alkanes with 4 carbon atoms (C₄H₁₀)
Alkanes with 5 carbon atoms (C₅H₁₂)
Alkanes with 6 carbon atoms (C₆H₁₄)

subsections.title: Naming Alkanes
points: Name is based on number of carbon atoms.
"Meth" = 1 carbon
"Eth" = 2 carbons
"Prop" = 3 carbons
And so on...

subsections.title: Types of Formulae
points: Molecular formula – shows number of each atom.
Structural formula – shows how atoms are bonded.
Condensed formula – groups atoms together.
Skeletal formula – uses lines to show carbon bonds.
Activity: Draw alkanes with 6, 7, 8, 9, and 10 carbon atoms.

subsections.title: Sources of Alkanes
subsections.content: Obtained by fractional distillation of crude oil.

subsections.title: Crude Oil
points: Thick, dark liquid with strong smell.
Formed from dead plants and animals over millions of years.
Contains many types of hydrocarbons.

subsections.title: Fractional Distillation
points: Heated in a furnace.
Vapors rise in a fractionating column (hot at bottom, cooler at top).
Lighter compounds rise higher; heavier ones condense at the bottom.
Final product is bitumen – used for roads.

subsections.title: Preparation of Alkanes (Methane)
subsections.content:
Heat sodium ethanoate with soda lime (NaOH + CaO).
Produces methane and sodium carbonate.
points: Equation: CnH₂n+1COONa + NaOH → CH₄ + Na₂CO₃

subsections.title: Physical Properties of Alkanes
points: Colourless
Insoluble in water
Soluble in organic solvents

subsections.title: Methane Specific Properties
points: Colourless, odourless gas
Less dense than air

subsections.title: Chemical Properties of Alkanes
subsections.content: 1. Combustion: Burn in oxygen to give CO₂ and H₂O. Release energy.
points: Complete combustion: Blue, hot, clean flame. Example: 2C₂H₆ + 7O₂ → 4CO₂ + 6H₂O
Incomplete combustion: Yellow, sooty flame. Example: CH₄ + O₂ → C + 2H₂O
2. Substitution Reactions: Hydrogen replaced by halogens (Cl, Br, I).
Steps:
CH₄ + Cl₂ → CH₃Cl + HCl (Monochloromethane)
CH₃Cl + Cl₂ → CH₂Cl₂ + HCl (Dichloromethane)
CH₂Cl₂ + Cl₂ → CHCl₃ + HCl (Chloroform)
CHCl₃ + Cl₂ → CCl₄ + HCl (Carbon tetrachloride)

subsections.title: Uses of Alkanes
points: Fuels (cooking, cars, machines)
Candle wax
Vaseline and grease
Polish
Lab solvents
Bitumen for roads

subsections.title: Introduction to Alkenes
subsections.content:
Alkenes are unsaturated hydrocarbons.
They contain at least one double covalent bond between two carbon atoms.
General formula: CₙH₂ₙ.
"Unsaturated" means the molecule does not contain the maximum number of hydrogen atoms due to the double bond.
The first member of the alkene group is ethene (C₂H₄).
points:
Structure of Ethene:

  H       H                       H       H
   C  =  C        OR              C  =  C
   H       H                       H       H

subsections.title: Naming of Alkenes
subsections.content: Based on the number of carbon atoms (same prefixes as alkanes):
points: Ethene (2C), Propene (3C), Butene (4C), Pentene (5C), etc.

subsections.title: Sources of Alkenes
points: A. Dehydration of Alcohols: Removal of water from alcohol using concentrated acids like sulphuric acid (H₂SO₄) or phosphoric acid (H₃PO₄). On heating, alcohol is converted into an alkene + water.
General Equation: CₙH₂ₙ₊₁OH → CₙH₂ₙ + H₂O (alcohol → alkene + water).
Experiment: Preparation of Ethene from Ethanol.
Chemicals/Apparatus: Ethanol, Conc. sulphuric acid, Bromine water, Acidified potassium permanganate (KMnO₄).
Procedure: Mix ethanol and conc. H₂SO₄, heat the mixture. Ethene gas is produced and bubbled through testing solutions.
Observations: Gas is released, which decolorizes bromine water and acidified KMnO₄ confirming unsaturation (ethene).
Reactions:
Step 1 (formation of ethyl hydrogen sulphate): C₂H₅OH + H₂SO₄ → C₂H₅HSO₄ + H₂O.
Step 2 (production of ethene): C₂H₅HSO₄ → C₂H₄ + H₂SO₄.
Notes: Reaction is exothermic and must be cooled. Alcohol and acid are miscible. Dry porcelain promotes smooth boiling. Ethene gas is flammable and explosive; release first portion safely.

subsections.title: Sources of Alkenes (continued)
points: B. Cracking of Hydrocarbons: Breaking long-chain hydrocarbons into shorter alkanes and alkenes.
Example: C₆H₁₄ → C₄H₁₀ + C₂H₄ (Hexane → Butane + Ethene).
Uses of Cracking: Produces more petrol and improves fuel quality through blending.
Types of Cracking: Thermal cracking (high temperature), Catalytic cracking (heat + catalyst like Al₂O₃, SiO₂) at lower temperatures.

subsections.title: Physical Properties of Alkenes
subsections.content: Ethene is a colourless, odourless gas.
points: Insoluble in water.
Soluble in organic solvents.
States of first 6 alkenes:
Gases: C₂H₄, C₃H₆, C₄H₈.
Liquids: C₅H₁₀, C₆H₁₂.
Boiling/melting points increase with the number of carbon atoms due to higher molecular mass.

subsections.title: Chemical Properties of Alkenes
points: A. Combustion: Alkenes burn in air to produce CO₂ and H₂O. Highly flammable.
Equation: C₂H₄ + 3O₂ → 2CO₂ + 2H₂O.
B. Addition Reactions:
1. Hydrogenation: Ethene + hydrogen → ethane (requires nickel catalyst at ~150°C). Equation: C₂H₄ + H₂ → C₂H₆.

Structure:
  H      H                  H     H
   C = C  +  H–H  →  H–C – C–H
   H      H                  H     H
2. Hydration: Ethene reacts with conc. H₂SO₄ to form ethyl hydrogen sulphate, which then reacts with water to produce ethanol.
Step 1: C₂H₄ + H₂SO₄ → C₂H₅OSO₃H.
Step 2: C₂H₅OSO₃H + H₂O → C₂H₅OH + H₂SO₄.
Alternative industrial method: C₂H₄ + H₂O (steam) → C₂H₅OH (ethanol production).
3. Halogenation: Alkenes react with halogens (Cl₂, Br₂, I₂) across the double bond to form dihalides.
Bromine water test identifies alkenes by decolorization.
Example: C₂H₄ + Br₂ → C₂H₄Br₂ (Brown → Colourless).

Structure:
  H     H                  H     H
   C = C  +  Br–Br  →  H–C – C–H
   H     H                  Br    Br

subsections.title: Test for Unsaturation
points: Bromine water: Alkenes turn brown bromine water colourless.
Acidified KMnO₄: Purple solution becomes colourless.

subsections.title: Uses of Alkenes
points: Production of plastics (polyethene from ethene).
Artificial ripening of fruits (e.g., bananas, mangoes).
Industrial alcohol production (ethanol from ethene).
Making paints, antifreeze, and detergents.

subsections.title: Nature of Air
subsections.content: Air is a mixture of gases.

subsections.title: The Need for Air
points: Breathing
Burning fuels
Maintains warmth
Brings wind and rain

subsections.title: Percentage Composition of Dry Air (By Volume)
subsections.content: Substance and their approximate percentage composition in dry air:
points: Nitrogen (N₂) - 78%
Oxygen (O₂) - 21%
Carbon dioxide (CO₂) - 0.03%
Noble gases - About 1%
Dust/smoke - Variable
Polluting gases - Variable

subsections.title: Uses of Gases Found in Air
points: 1. Nitrogen: Dilutes oxygen, reducing its reactivity; prevents excess rusting and burning; used to make ammonia and nitric acid.
2. Oxygen: Supports breathing, burning, rusting, and decay; essential for life.
3. Carbon Dioxide (CO₂): Comes from burning wood, coal, petrol; used by green plants in photosynthesis; used in preserving soft drinks and beer.
4. Noble Gases (He, Ne, Ar, Kr, Xe): Inert gases that do not react under ordinary conditions; Argon in electric bulbs; Helium in weather balloons; Neon in colourful advertising signs.

subsections.title: Separation of Air Components by Fractional Distillation of Liquid Air
points: Air is first cleaned (removal of CO₂, water vapour, dust) to prevent blockage.
Compressed to ~200 atm – air becomes hot.
Cooled and expanded to become very cold and liquefy.
At -200°C, N₂, O₂, and argon liquefy; helium and neon remain gaseous and are removed.
Fractional distillation separates gases by boiling points:
Nitrogen (N₂) boils at -196°C – collected first.
Argon (Ar) at -186°C.
Oxygen (O₂) at -183°C.

subsections.title: Physical Properties of Oxygen (O₂)
points: Slightly soluble in water.
Slightly denser than air.
Neutral gas – not acidic or basic.
Colourless and odourless.

subsections.title: Experiment: Effect of O₂ on Litmus
subsections.content: Apparatus: Blue & red litmus paper, gas jar of O₂.
points: Observation: No colour change.
Conclusion: O₂ is neutral.

subsections.title: Experiment: Solubility of O₂
subsections.content: Apparatus: Gas jar of O₂, trough, distilled water.
points: Observation: Water level slightly rises.
Conclusion: O₂ is slightly soluble in water.

subsections.title: Chemical Properties of Oxygen
subsections.content: 1. Reaction with Non-Metals:
points: a. Sulphur: Burns with blue flame to form sulphur dioxide (SO₂). Equation: S + O₂ → SO₂.
SO₂ is acidic; turns blue litmus red and forms sulphurous acid: SO₂ + H₂O → H₂SO₃.
b. Carbon: Burns with red glow to form carbon dioxide (CO₂). Equation: C + O₂ → CO₂.
Forms carbonic acid in water: CO₂ + H₂O → H₂CO₃.
c. Phosphorus: Burns to form P₂O₃ (limited O₂) and P₂O₅ (excess O₂); both are acidic oxides and form H₃PO₃ and H₃PO₄ in water.
2. Reaction with Metals:
i. Magnesium (Mg): Mg + O₂ → MgO; MgO + H₂O → Mg(OH)₂ (alkaline).
ii. Sodium (Na): Na + O₂ → Na₂O; Excess O₂ forms sodium peroxide (Na₂O₂). Sodium peroxide reacts with water to form NaOH and O₂.
iii. Iron (Fe): Burns with yellow sparks to form Fe₂O₃; brown-black oxide, insoluble, non-alkaline.
iv. Calcium (Ca): Burns with red flame to form CaO; CaO + H₂O → Ca(OH)₂ (limewater).
v. Copper (Cu): Burns with blue-green flame to form CuO; black oxide, insoluble, non-alkaline.

subsections.title: Laboratory Preparation of Oxygen (O₂)
subsections.content: Method: Oxygen is prepared by decomposing hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂).
points: Word equation: Hydrogen peroxide → Water + Oxygen.
Chemical equation: 2H₂O₂ (aq) → 2H₂O (l) + O₂ (g).
Hydrogen peroxide is a colourless liquid that decomposes slowly on its own.
Manganese dioxide (MnO₂) acts as a catalyst to speed up the reaction and remains unchanged.
Complete reaction with catalyst: 2H₂O₂ (aq) —MnO₂→ 2H₂O (l) + O₂ (g).

subsections.title: Experiment: Preparation and Properties of Oxygen
subsections.content: Aim: To prepare and observe properties of oxygen gas.
points: Materials: Flask, trough, water, gas jars.
Chemicals: Hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂), Manganese dioxide (MnO₂).
Observation: Bubbles of gas form and collect; gas is colourless and odourless.
Test: Insert glowing splint into gas jar; positive test if splint relights, confirming O₂ presence.

subsections.title: Uses of Oxygen
points: Used in removal of impurities during steel manufacturing.
Used in explosives with charcoal, petrol, and liquid oxygen.
Breathing aid for diving, high-altitude climbing, and hospitals.
Used in welding and cutting metals (oxy-acetylene, oxy-hydrogen flames).
Liquid oxygen burns fuel in rockets and spacecraft.

subsections.title: Atmospheric Pollutants and Sources
points: i. Atmospheric Pollution: Addition of harmful substances into the atmosphere causing dirty environment and health/environmental hazards.
ii. Atmospheric Pollutants: Two main categories – Poisonous gases and Solid particles.

subsections.title: Poisonous Gases
subsections.content: a. Sulphur Dioxide (SO₂):
points: Source: Burning fossil fuels containing sulphur.
Equation: S + O₂ → SO₂.
Effects: Toxic, respiratory problems, causes acid rain damaging buildings and metals.

subsections.title: Poisonous Gases
subsections.content: b. Nitrogen Dioxide (NO₂):
points: Formed by nitrogen combining with oxygen during lightning and combustion.
Equation: N₂ + O₂ → 2NO → NO₂.
Effects: Toxic, respiratory issues, acid rain.

subsections.title: Poisonous Gases
subsections.content: c. Carbon Monoxide (CO):
points: Formed during incomplete combustion.
Equation: C + ½O₂ → CO.
Effects: Very poisonous, colourless, odourless; binds with red blood cells preventing oxygen transport, potentially fatal.

subsections.title: Poisonous Gases
subsections.content: d. Carbon Dioxide (CO₂):
points: Causes greenhouse effect by trapping warm air.
Effects include global warming, melting polar ice, rising sea levels, coastal flooding.

subsections.title: Poisonous Gases
subsections.content: e. Unburnt Hydrocarbons:
points: Emitted from petrol fumes.
Carcinogenic – may cause cancer.

subsections.title: Poisonous Gases
subsections.content: f. Chlorine (Cl₂):
points: Released from decomposition of insecticides and perfumes.
Destroys ozone layer.

subsections.title: Poisonous Gases
subsections.content: g. Ozone (O₃):
points: Form of oxygen; blue gas.
In upper atmosphere (12–50 km): traps UV rays (good).
In lower atmosphere: causes headaches, damages crops and lungs (harmful).
Ozone depletion causes cancer, skin irritation, death.
Caused by CFCs and other gases.
Mitigation: Avoid CFC use, prevent O₃ formation at ground level.

subsections.title: Solid Particles
subsections.content: Suspended particulates come from mining, cement/flour industries, quarrying, burning charcoal/tyres, construction.
points: Examples: Carbon particles from inefficient fuel combustion, dust (fine powder waste).
Effects: Respiratory disease, brain damage, cancer.

subsections.title: Ways to Reduce Atmospheric Pollution
points: Improve fuel combustion in petrol/diesel engines.
Use smokeless fuels like hydrogen.
Install efficient filters in industries.
Process fuels to remove sulphur compounds.

subsections.title: Review Questions
points: What is chemical pollution? Contamination of environment by harmful chemicals from human activity.
Name two poisonous gases: Sulphur dioxide (SO₂), Carbon monoxide (CO).
Which gas causes global warming? Carbon dioxide (CO₂).
Which gas causes ozone damage? Chlorine gas (Cl₂).
How can global warming and ozone damage be prevented? Reduce CO₂ emissions by using clean fuels; avoid CFCs and limit aerosols/insecticides; encourage reforestation and energy efficiency.

subsections.title: Composition of Soil
subsections.content: Soil is composed of the following four main components:
points: Inorganic Matter
Organic Matter
Water (Moisture)
Air

subsections.title: Inorganic Matter
subsections.content: Comprises weathered rock particles and minerals, making up about 50% of soil content.
points: Sand
Silt
Clay
Mineral elements such as Iron (Fe), Aluminium (Al), Copper (Cu)
Groups of Mineral Elements in Soil: Silicates, Macronutrients, Trace Elements

subsections.title: Organic Matter
subsections.content: Makes up approximately 5% of the soil. Composed of animal waste and humus.
points: Humus results from the decomposition of plant and animal remains by bacteria and fungi.
Role of Humus: Regulates soil pH (acidity or alkalinity) and increases soil fertility.
Relationship Between Humus and pH: More humus = Higher pH (more alkaline)
Higher humus content = Greater soil fertility

subsections.title: Water (Moisture)
subsections.content: Constitutes about 25% of soil, known as soil water.
points: Dissolves mineral salts for plant uptake.
Excess moisture may cause waterlogging, reducing soil oxygen and limiting bacterial activity necessary for humus formation.
Anaerobic conditions occur when oxygen is lacking.

subsections.title: Air
subsections.content: Also makes up about 25% of soil, found in spaces between soil particles (soil pores).
points: Contains Oxygen (O₂), Nitrogen (N₂), Carbon dioxide (CO₂), Noble gases (Helium, Neon, Argon).
Proportions of Gases in Soil Air: Nitrogen (78%), Oxygen (21%), Carbon Dioxide (0.2–0.6%), Others (traces)

subsections.title: Chemical Properties of Soil
points: Cation Exchange Capacity (CEC): Amount of exchangeable ions in 100g soil (e.g., Ca²⁺, K⁺, Na⁺).
High exchangeable sodium soils can be toxic to crops.
Soil Salinity: Amount of salts in soil per unit mass; saline soils contain excess salts harmful to plants.
Soil pH: Indicates acidity or alkalinity, determined by hydrogen ion concentration; high H⁺ means more acidic soil.

subsections.title: Activity
points: 1. Name the four main components of soil.
2. Which component determines the pH of the soil?
3. Define the following terms: a. Cation Exchange Capacity (CEC) b. Soil Salinity c. Soil pH
4. Describe what determines soil acidity.

subsections.title: Adjusting Soil Acidity
points: To Raise pH (Reduce Acidity): Apply lime (calcium compounds), use basic fertilizers.
To Lower pH (Increase Acidity): Apply sulphur, use acidic fertilizers like ammonium sulphate [(NH₄)₂SO₄].
Reaction: NH₄⁺ + SO₄²⁻ → (NH₄)₂SO₄

subsections.title: Soil Pollution
subsections.content: Soil pollution is the release of harmful substances into the soil from human activities.
points: Pollutant: Any substance contaminating soil, water, or air.

subsections.title: Sources and Effects of Soil Pollutants
points: Sulphur Oxides (SO₂, SO₃): Released via acid rain; lowers soil pH, causes nutrient leaching and fertility loss.
Aerosols: Sprays with heavy metals (copper, mercury); toxic to animals and soil microorganisms.
Petroleum Products: Oil spills suffocate soil organisms by blocking oxygen.
Agro-Chemicals: Fertilizers, insecticides, fungicides cause toxicity and alter soil chemistry.
Solid Waste: Household/industrial waste harms soil structure, reduces aeration, attracts pests.

subsections.title: Prevention of Soil Pollution
points: Recycle all solid wastes.
Burn biodegradable wastes using incinerators.
Practice organic farming (no chemicals).
Use biological pest control to reduce pesticide use.
Use pipelines to transport fuel and avoid spills.

subsections.title: Definition and Properties
subsections.content: Acids release H⁺ ions in water while bases release OH⁻ ions. Their strength is measured by pH.
points: Acids have pH less than 7.
Bases (alkalis) have pH greater than 7.
Strong acids and bases dissociate completely in water.

subsections.title: Examples
subsections.content: Common acids and bases used in labs and industry.
points: Acids: Hydrochloric acid (HCl), Sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄), Nitric acid (HNO₃).
Bases: Sodium hydroxide (NaOH), Ammonium hydroxide (NH₄OH).

subsections.title: Neutralization Reaction
subsections.content: Neutralization is a chemical reaction between an acid and a base.
points: Produces salt and water.
Example: HCl + NaOH → NaCl + H₂O.
Used in antacids and agriculture (liming soil).

subsections.title: Definition
subsections.content: Matter exists in different states based on particle arrangement and energy.
points: Solid, liquid, and gas are the three main physical states of matter.

subsections.title: Properties of States
subsections.content: Each state has unique characteristics.
points: Solids: Fixed shape and volume, particles closely packed.
Liquids: No fixed shape, fixed volume, particles slide over each other.
Gases: No fixed shape or volume, particles move freely and are compressible.

subsections.title: Changes of State
subsections.content: Matter can change from one state to another by gaining or losing energy.
points: Melting: Solid to liquid.
Boiling: Liquid to gas.
Condensation: Gas to liquid.
Freezing: Liquid to solid.
Sublimation: Solid to gas without becoming liquid.
